title: Connecticut Governor Promises More Education, Transportation Spending
summary: Ned Lamont also called for paid family leave and a $15 minimum wage in his first official address to lawmakers. Connecticut Gov. Ned Lamont pledged in his first official address to state lawmakers Wednesday to invest more in the state's urban centers, boost spending on education and improve an aging transportation system.

title: Judge Reopens Bankruptcy Case, Citing Allegations McKinsey Hid Investments
summary: Reopening of Alpha Natural Resources' chapter 11 adds to McKinsey's legal headaches over disclosure practices. A bankruptcy judge decided to reopen coal-mining company Alpha Natural Resources' 2015 chapter 11 case, saying allegations that adviser McKinsey & Co. hid investments that gave it a financial stake in the outcome of the case are among the most serious he has ever seen.

title: 'The First Conspiracy' Review: The Skulduggery of King George
summary: In 1776, the British schemed to destabilize the fledgling American Revolution. Did their plans include the assassination of George Washington? Stephen Brumwell reviews "The First Conspiracy" by Brad Meltzer and Josh Mensch.. Late in the morning of June 28, 1776, a dense crowd thronged a field near New York's Bowery to witness the execution of Continental Army private Thomas Hickey. A stocky, swarthy Irishman who had served in the British army before deserting and enlisting in the rebel forces now fighting for independence, he was sentenced to hang for sedition and mutiny and treasonous dealings with the "enemies of the United American Colonies."

title: U.S. Dollar Falls After Dovish Fed Comments
summary: Two Federal Reserve officials see little need for raising interest rates in the near-term. The U.S. dollar fell broadly against both developed and emerging-market currencies Wednesday after two Federal Reserve officials suggested there is little need for policy makers to raise interest rates in the near-term.

title: How to Keep the Lights on in California
summary: PG&E's investors and customers are facing unpleasant choices to pay for the cost of wildfires, but there is a way to minimize and share the costs.

title: Disney's Former Animation Chief Lands New Job
summary: John Lasseter, who left Disney under a cloud, joins Skydance Media. LOS ANGELES-John Lasseter, the former head of Walt Disney Co. 's animation studios, has joined Skydance Media as the head of animation, six months after he was ousted at Disney following allegations of inappropriately touching colleagues.

title: De Blasio Proposes Law Mandating Paid Vacation in NYC
summary: Law would give paid time off to the 500,000 workers who receive none from their employers, says mayor. Mayor Bill de Blasio proposed legislation on Wednesday that would require employers to provide paid vacation, making New York the first city in the nation to mandate this type of leave.

title: U.S. Food Inspections Slow Amid Government Shutdown
summary: The FDA is working to resume inspections of facilities deemed high-risk. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has dramatically curtailed inspections of domestic food-processing facilities during the partial government shutdown, though it is now trying to resume work at the most high-risk sites.

title: Fed Is Unlikely to Raise Rates in Next Months
summary: Recent market volatility and signs of slowing global growth made 'extent and timing of further policy firming less clear'. WASHINGTON-Federal Reserve officials signaled they are unlikely to raise interest rates for at least a few months while they assess the impact of recent market volatility on the U.S. economy.

title: Councilman Proposes Panel to Assess NYPD's Handling of Hate Groups
summary: The bill is motivated by increase in hate crimes in New York City. In response to a rise in hate crimes in New York City last year, a Queens councilman announced legislation on Wednesday that would create a task force to evaluate the New York Police Department's strategy for combating hate groups.

title: ABB Bets Simplified Structure Will Cut Costs, Boost Profit
summary: Swiss conglomerate expects to reduce head count at headquarters. Industrial giant ABB Ltd. is putting more power in the hands of its business leaders and reducing head count at its corporate office in a bid to boost its profit margin and cut $500 million a year in costs.

title: Au Pairs Reach $65.5 Million Settlement Over Wages
summary: Payout is result of 2014 class-action lawsuit alleging au pairs were unjustly paid below minimum wage. Sponsors of the nation's au pair program have agreed to pay $65.5 million under a settlement announced Wednesday that could reshape how foreign workers are paid to care for U.S. children.

title: Utilities Speed Up Closure of Coal-Fired Power Plants
summary: Wind, solar and natural gas become more cost-competitive, driving shift to new energy sources. Just last summer, Northern Indiana Public Service Co. planned to retire two of its five remaining coal-fired power plants by 2023. Now, it plans to do away with all of them over the next decade, and buy more solar and wind power instead.

title: Deputy AG Rosenstein Expected to Leave in Coming Weeks
summary: No signs Rosenstein, who has weathered criticism from President Trump over Mueller probe, is being forced out. WASHINGTON-Rod Rosenstein, the deputy attorney general who has tried for two years to steady a rocky Justice Department and its tumultuous relationship with the White House, plans to leave the job in coming weeks, people familiar with his thinking said Wednesday, raising the stakes for the confirmation process of President Trump's attorney general nominee, William Barr.

title: No Jumping on the Bed, Bath & Beyond
summary: The beleaguered home-goods retailer's shares surged after it reported results that were slightly better than modest expectations, but there is no sign of a real turnaround. Lower the bar far enough and you may be able to eke out a surprise win.

title: Iraq Urges Pompeo to Maintain U.S. Troop Presence in Country
summary: Secretary of state is on an eight-day tour amid consternation among allies that the U.S. is pulling out of the region. Iraqi leaders implored Secretary of State Mike Pompeo to maintain a U.S. troop presence in the country, seeking U.S. reassurances after the Trump administration announced plans to withdraw troops from elsewhere in the region.

title: Treasury Yields Hold Below 2018 Highs as Rate Doubts Mount
summary: U.S. government-bond prices fell but finished off their lows Wednesday after a number of Federal Reserve officials expressed further caution about the pace of future rate increases. U.S. government-bond prices fell but finished off their lows Wednesday after a number of Federal Reserve officials expressed further caution about the pace of future rate increases.

title: Beware the 5G Hype: Wireless Rivals Fuel Confusion
summary: AT&T, Verizon put their own spin on wireless standards to appear cutting-edge; some decry fake 5G. What's 5G wireless service? On this, companies can agree: It's what comes after 4G.

title: Infrastructure Projects May Start Feeling the Bite of Government Shutdown
summary: New and ongoing projects could be delayed, particularly as spring weather typically kicks off construction season on the nation's highways. State highway groups say the partial federal government shutdown could delay the start of new highway, bridge and other infrastructure projects across the U.S. if the budget impasse in Washington goes on much longer.

title: Iran Confirms Arrest of U.S. Navy Veteran
summary: Charges aren't disclosed, but Foreign Ministry spokesman says Tehran told U.S. of Michael White's detention shortly after it happened. Iran said it has arrested a U.S. Navy veteran on charges it didn't disclose, a move that threatens to further strain relations between Washington and Tehran after the Trump administration reimposed sanctions last year on the Islamic Republic.

title: Most New Voting Members of Fed Back Rate Pause
summary: Two hawks who previously pushed for boosts have joined a longtime dove in taking a wait-and-see stance on the economy. The final pieces of the puzzle fell into place on Wednesday that essentially ensure it will be months before the Fed contemplates another rate rise.

title: Push to Block Removal of Rusal Sanctions Heads Toward Failure
summary: Democrats are so far unable to secure Republican support needed to fight Treasury Department's proposed treatment of aluminum producer. An effort by Democratic lawmakers to block the Trump administration's proposal to cut a Russian aluminum giant from its sanctions blacklist appears likely to fail next week because of a lack of support from the president's Republican allies.

title: Portraits of Pain at the Prototype Festival
summary: The opera-theater festival's two big shows, 'prism' and '4.48 Psychosis,' portray varieties of mental chaos..

title: Los Angeles Teachers Strike Postponed
summary: Walkout in nation's second-largest school district moved to Monday as talks continue. The Los Angeles teachers union postponed the planned start date of a strike to Monday, as it continued talks with district officials aimed at averting a walkout in the nation's second-largest school district.

title: Longtime Queens District Attorney Won't Seek Re-Election
summary: Richard Brown, a Democrat, has served as the borough's district attorney for 27 years. The longtime Queens district attorney said Wednesday he wouldn't seek re-election, clearing the way for a competitive contest later this year and the possibility of a major shift in the borough's criminal-justice policy.

title: 'Why Hasn't Everything Already Disappeared?' by Deerhunter Review: A Statelier Kind of Chaos
summary: Deerhunter turns its concerned gaze outward on its new record, which does away with the lo-fi sound of its earlier music..

title: Skyworks Was Already Grounded
summary: Apple supplier's shares gain following warning, as bad iPhone news was already priced in. The sky isn't falling. In fact Skyworks , which depends heavily on sagging Apple Inc. for much of its business, saw its shares rise on Wednesday following bad news.

title: F1 Racing Champ Lewis Hamilton Buys Manhattan Penthouse for $40.7 Million
summary: The British star driver purchased a unit in a condo in New York's Tribeca district that is popular with celebrities; this is his second recent purchase in the neighborhood. Less than two years after snapping up a $43.991 million apartment in a celebrity-studded condo project in Manhattan's Tribeca district, British Formula One star Lewis Hamilton has struck again, this time buying a $40.7 million trophy penthouse in another big-name building a block away.

title: Fitch Ratings Lowers Expectations for PHI as Debt Maturities Loom
summary: Concern mounts that helicopter services provider has few options to meet March obligations, credit agency says. Fitch Ratings tagged PHI Inc. as a substantial credit risk, assigning a CCC- rating to the helicopter services operator on concerns the company may be unable to refinance $500 million in debt.

title: Fed Tries to Please Everyone
summary: Unlike the Fed Chairman Jerome Powell's recent pronouncements, the central bank's minutes didn't jolt markets. The release of minutes from the Federal Reserve's December meeting did something that the central bank has struggled to do lately: It elicited a yawn from investors.

title: White House Weighs Canceling Trump's Trip to Davos This Month
summary: President may skip World Economic Forum if shutdown isn't resolved by Jan. 22 start. WASHINGTON-President Trump's team is weighing canceling his trip to Davos, Switzerland, later this month if the partial government shutdown hasn't been solved by the Jan. 22 start of the annual World Economic Forum, administration officials said.

title: Oil Surges 5% on Saudi Support, U.S.-China Talks
summary: U.S. oil futures enter a bull market, climbing to a nearly four-week high. • U.S. oil prices technically entered a bull market Wednesday, surging to a nearly four-week high as the Saudis pushed for higher prices and the U.S. and China appeared to make progress toward resolving their trade dispute. Investors shrugged off another bearish report on U.S. oil inventories.

summary: Chiefs at Johnson & Johnson, CVS discuss what's next on a range of industry issues. One of the biggest health conferences of the year for investors, the J.P. title: Fuel Crisis Hits Mexico After Pipelines Are Closed
summary: López Obrador administration move to transport gasoline by trucks to prevent massive pipeline theft by organized crime groups sparks consumer panic. MEXICO CITY-Mexico faced a mounting crisis on Wednesday as gasoline shortages spread across the country after the government closed several key fuel pipelines to prevent theft by organized crime groups.

title: Kidnapping of Norwegian Multimillionaire's Spouse Revealed
summary: Anne Elisabeth Hagen has been missing since Oct. 31, police say, seeking news of her whereabouts. The wife of a Norwegian multimillionaire real-estate tycoon was abducted more than two months ago, police said on Wednesday, gripping public attention in the rich Nordic country.

title: Constellation Lowers Outlook After Earnings Miss
summary: Constellation Brands reports drop in quarterly profit, lowers year targets. Constellation Brands Inc. has bet much of its future on cannabis, but until then the big beer and wine company is struggling with slumping demand for cheap wines such as its Ravenswood Merlot and Cook's California Champagne.

title: Bank of Canada Holds Key Rate Steady at 1.75%
summary: Central bank says low global oil prices will weigh on 2019 growth. OTTAWA-The Bank of Canada held its key interest rate steady at 1.75% as weak global oil prices prompted it to lower its growth forecast for this year and pause further rate increases.

title: Saudi Arabia Sells More Than $7 Billion in Bonds
summary: The nation's reputation as a reliable bet for debt investors had taken a hit since Jamal Khashoggi's death. DUBAI-Saudi Arabia sold $7.5 billion in bonds Wednesday, drawing support from international investors in the kingdom's first debt sale since the killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi.

title: The Many Places Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos Calls Home
summary: The Amazon chief owns multiple properties, including more than 300,000 acres in Texas. In choosing a site for the company's second headquarters, known as HQ2, will he seek a spot close to home?. As the world waits to see where Amazon locates its second headquarters, one clue might lie in the rule of thumb of second-home buying: Pick a location that's not too far from home. In the case of Amazon chief Jeff Bezos, that's still a pretty wide field.

title: New Jersey Governor Calls for Ending State's Current Corporate Tax Incentives
summary: Audit finds economic development agency wasn't able to accurately track whether tax-credits created promised jobs. New Jersey Gov. Phil Murphy on Wednesday called for state lawmakers to end the current corporate tax-incentive programs and create a new, pared-back version after an audit questioned whether the programs succeed at creating jobs.

title: Former U.K. Prime Minister Gordon Brown to Advise Private-Equity Firm
summary: Ex-Treasury chief will counsel Switzerland's Partners Group on so-called impact investments. Former British Prime Minister Gordon Brown is following the well-trodden path from politics to private equity.

title: Advocates Condemn Prison Sentence for Turkish Journalist
summary: Pelin Ünker received 13 months in prison for her Paradise Papers reporting. Advocates condemned the prison sentence handed down on a Turkish journalist who reported on findings from a leak that included records of financial dealings by her country's former prime minister and two of his sons.

title: The Hotel Fees That Barely Even Make Sense
summary: Hotels have gotten creative in fattening your bill while offering questionable perks in return-what is a destination fee, anyway?. The push by hotels to swamp travelers with fees is expanding: The fees you used to only find at resorts are moving downtown.

title: Stars Align for an Opportunity in Constellation Brands
summary: Shares of the brewer are cheap as investors overreact to margin and growth concerns. Constellation Brands has been through a rough few months, but its fundamental growth story hasn't changed.

title: President Must Surmount the Wall Obstacle
summary: The Democrats have laid a trap for President Trump, similar to the one they laid for George H.W. Bush.. Regarding Daniel Henninger's "Trump at the Turn" (Wonder Land, Jan. 3): I believe Mr. Henninger has missed the essential reasons for the government shutdown.

title: Deter Crime With Certainty of Consequence
summary: The brilliance of "broken windows" is in the fact that an intervention is taken regarding a crime, whether it is a serious one or a nuisance.. Regarding William McGurn's "The Weekend Interview with George L. Kelling: The Idea That Made America's Cities Safer" (Dec. 29): The brilliance of "broken windows" isn't in the number of arrests or in the numbers of those incarcerated in our city, county and state jails or prisons. Rather, it is in the fact that an intervention is taken regarding a crime, whether it is a serious one or a nuisance.

title: The Info Companies Bow to Totalitarian Idol
summary: The Airbnbs, Apples and all other information-marketing franchises must face the reality that their revenue growth is limited in totalitarian countries unless they, too, subscribe to totalitarian legal standards.. Crispin Sartwell's analysis of China's legal ability to monitor all its citizens' activities highlights the underlying conflict between First Amendment rights guaranteed by the U.S. Constitution and their absence in totalitarian countries ("What's Worse Than Facebook?," op-ed, Jan. 7). Totalitarian state-based companies competing in world markets are able to limit market access to their countries' markets to competitors such as Facebook and other First Amendment-based marketing franchises.

title: Airbus Order Rate Slackened in 2018
summary: European passenger-jet maker still has huge backlog and remains upbeat about global demand from airlines. Airbus SE said Wednesday that it booked fewer airliner orders in 2018 and trailed U.S. rival Boeing Co. for the year, but the European plane maker remained upbeat about global demand for air travel.

title: Political Correctness Is a Formula for Mediocre Art
summary: Art will continue to be safe and bland to avoid backlash in our outrage culture.. Regarding Peggy Noonan's "Baby, There's a Chilling Effect Outside" (Declarations, Jan. 5): Political correctness has already destroyed entertainment. Rarely does anything on mainstream radio, television or in studio films provide product that is thought provoking, risky or potentially offensive to the loud minority. Art will continue to be safe and bland to avoid backlash in our outrage culture.

title: Admiral Yamamoto Doesn't Deserve the Opprobrium
summary: If there is such a thing as an honorable enemy it was Isoroku Yamamoto.. I was appalled to read in Jason Willick's "A Case of Mistaken Identity Politics in the Heart of Silicon Valley" (Cross Country, Dec. 29) that misguided Chinese-Americans oppose naming a California school after American soldier Fred Yamamoto, simply because he shares a name with Japanese Admiral Isoroku Yamamoto. If anything, they should celebrate Yamamoto as an honorable warrior who opposed the Japanese army's aggression in China and the tripartite pact with Nazi Germany-to the extent that his friends in the government assigned him to a sea command to prevent his assassination. Yamamato had nothing to do with Japanese atrocities in China and went to war with America grudgingly, warning that it would doom Japan. If there is an honorable enemy, it was Isoroku Yamamoto.

title: If You Have to Ask How Much Socialized Medicine Costs...
summary: Democrats know taxpayers will realize they can't afford it.. After dismissing for years the idea that Democrats' health care plans would lead to a government takeover, new House Budget Committee Chairman John Yarmuth on Tuesday asked Congress' top economist to sketch out the options for a government takeover. The Kentucky Democrat also implicitly sketched out the political game plan: enact socialized medicine before patients and taxpayers understand what they'll be losing.

title: Rosengren Says Fed Can Wait for Clarity Before Next Rate Move
summary: Boston Fed leader says current monetary policy seems appropriate for now. Federal Reserve Bank of Boston President Eric Rosengren said Wednesday he is willing to hold off on more rate increases until there is greater clarity over the economic outlook.

title: Mexico's Inflation Slowed in 2018
summary: Consumer price index rose 4.83% compared with 6.77% in 2017, but rise was still above central bank's 3% target. MEXICO CITY-Inflation in Mexico eased in 2018 from the previous year but not enough to keep the Bank of Mexico from raising interest rates four times during the year.

title: Trump Threatens to Block Emergency Funds for California Fire Relief
summary: President calls for state officials to 'get their act together' following devastating damage in recent months. President Trump on Wednesday threatened to halt the flow of federal emergency relief funds to California unless officials there "get their act together" to prevent forest fires that have ravaged the state in recent months, killing dozens and destroying thousands of homes.

title: A New Take on Women and Aging
summary: Clinical psychologist Mary Pipher explores the stereotypes and challenges of getting older and the survival skills women need to be happy. Twenty-five years ago and then in her 40s, clinical psychologist Mary Pipher wrote "Reviving Ophelia," a seminal book about adolescent girls. Now Dr. Pipher is exploring women getting older and finds this stage too, like teenage years, is a time of dealing with changing bodies, expectations and stereotypes.

title: U.S. Citizen Charged With Spying in Russia Could See Lengthy Detention
summary: Paul Whelan's lawyer says his client is handling his time in a Moscow jail with 'dignity, with humor and hope'. MOSCOW-Paul Whelan, the U.S. citizen detained by Russian authorities and charged with espionage, could remain in custody for six months or more as the investigation into his case continues, his lawyer said Wednesday.

summary: The head of Israeli internal security has warned that a foreign country plans to meddle in the vote. TEL AVIV-Israel is prepared to prevent any foreign attempts to interfere in its April elections, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Wednesday, after the head of Israel's internal security agency warned that a foreign country intends to meddle in the vote.

summary: The Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago president said the first half of this year very important to determine the course of monetary policy. title: A Historic Tuscan Manor Changing Hands After Centuries
summary: Likely built for one of the Medicis, a 2-acre estate that sheltered a sibling of Napoleon and was owned by a perfecter of Chianti wine is now listed for $2.8 million. Bonaparte, Romanov and Puccini are just three of the prominent names associated with Italy's Villa Studiati Berni, a grand Tuscan manor halfway between Pisa and Lucca.

title: Treasury Yields Rise Ahead of Fed Minutes
summary: Bond yields are on track to notch their fourth straight advance. U.S. government-bond prices weakened Wednesday ahead of the release of minutes from the Federal Reserve's December meeting and hopes of progress on the U.S. and China's trade talks.

title: Standoff Over Stranded Migrants Ends as Europe Opens Doors
summary: European Union members have struggled to find a unified response to uncontrolled migration. title: Conversations With Ingmar Bergman Become 'Unquiet'

title: Know Enough Not to Act Like a Know-It-All
summary: Executives who act like they have all the answers often reject input from others-to their detriment. But recovery is possible. Ambitious executives often act like they know everything. title: The Restaurateurs Behind Hart's and Cervo's Open a New Wine Bar in Brooklyn
summary: The Fly, with a menu centered on rotisserie chicken, will open this month. WHAT DOES breakout success mean for a business built on the idea of the neighborhood restaurant? Is it possible to scale up without compromising the recipe? For Leah Campbell, Nialls Fallon and Nick Perkins, the New York restaurateurs behind Hart's, Cervo's and the new wine bar The Fly-opening in late January-the answer so far is yes. On a Friday night at Hart's, their 800-square-foot hideaway in Brooklyn's Bedford-Stuyvesant area, Mediterranean-style dishes-head-on prawns, salty-sweet clam toast-emerge from the tiny kitchen as the five-seat bar buzzes with conversation and Michael Jackson's "Workin' Day and Night" plays in the background. "We want our places to feel like a party when you walk in the door, even if it's 5:30 and you're the only one in the restaurant," says Fallon, 32, who oversees the front of house and beverages.

title: Who Foots the Bill? Families Fight Over College Debt
summary: As tuition increases outpace household incomes and parents face a battery of other financial pressures, conflict over college debt is intensifying among American families. title: A New Stimulus Can't Keep Chinese Auto Stocks at Top Speed
summary: Any rerun of past efforts to rev up China's car market will only provide diminishing returns. The wheels came off for Chinese car makers last year, with sales set for their first annual fall in almost three decades. A fresh stimulus package from Beijing would provide a short-term fix, but only by borrowing from the future.

title: It's Not Easy Being a Chinese Bank
summary: Some officials have harangued banks for lending too much to state-owned enterprises and not enough to private companies. Chinese banks need to lend more to private enterprises. Too bad that won't help their credit profiles.

title: Fed Meeting Minutes Will Show How Officials Judged Economic Risks
summary: Market volatility bookended the Fed's short-term rate increase on Dec. 19. The Federal Reserve releases the minutes of its Dec. 18-19 meeting on Wednesday at 2 p.m. EST, providing more detail about how central bank officials viewed the risks to economic growth when they raised interest rates during a period of heightened market volatility.

title: U.S. Government Shutdown Paralyzes IPOs, Imperiling Expectations for 2019
summary: Biotech firms could be put in the most perilous position by the closure of the SEC. The government shutdown is threatening to spoil what was poised to be a banner year for IPOs.

title: Chinese Retail Apocalypse, Now?
summary: Panicky sentiment is being amplified by misleading numbers. It used to be that U.S. consumers were the world economy's main engine. Recently, several hundred million new spenders across the Pacific have become a major force too-huge profit drivers for Detroit, Hollywood and nearly every type of consumer-good vendor.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription.

title: Trump Makes His Case for a Border Wall
summary: President, in address, pitches funding of a barrier on the border to end the impasse. WASHINGTON-President Trump in a prime-time address Tuesday said a wall along the southern border is key to national security, as he called for lawmakers to fund it and end a partial government shutdown that is days away from becoming the longest in U.S. history.

title: China's Currency Proves a Surprise Oasis of Calm
summary: Resume Subscription. Despite recent turmoil in financial markets, the Chinese yuan has been surprisingly stable, as trade talks between Beijing and Washington continue and other pressures eased.

title: Who Is More Macho?
summary: Trump and Democrats talk past one another again on immigration.. The dialogue of the deaf that is America's immigration debate was on full display Tuesday night as President Trump and Democratic Congressional leaders talked past one another to an American public that could be forgiven for tuning out and returning to more illuminating programming like "The Bachelor."

title: Sears Gets Another Lifeline: Lampert's $4.4 Billion Bid Still Alive
summary: Former CEO Edward Lampert plans to participate in bankruptcy auction on Jan. 14. Billionaire Edward Lampert will get one last chance to keep Sears Holdings Corp. from closing down, after the retailer agreed to let its longtime leader compete in a bankruptcy auction that will decide the once-iconic department store's fate.

title: Democratic Leaders Denounce Wall and Trump 'Hostage' Tactics
summary: Pelosi and Schumer demand end to shutdown in televised response to immigration speech. Congressional Democratic leaders rebuffed President Trump's assertions on Tuesday night that a wall is needed along the border with Mexico and said he is manufacturing a crisis over immigration.

title: Key Numbers Behind Immigration
summary: Trump cites crime and costs associated with illegal immigration; Democrats say he overstates the problem. Cracking down on illegal immigration was a central piece of President Donald Trump's campaign for the White House and is now at the center of his fight with Congress over funding for a wall on the border with Mexico.

title: Herbalife CEO Goudis Resigns
summary: Head of nutritional-supplement company steps down after it says it discovered comments inconsistent with its culture. Herbalife Nutrition Ltd. 's chief executive has resigned after the company said it discovered comments he made prior to becoming CEO that were inconsistent with its standards.

title: Carlos Ghosn in Wonderland
summary: The case against the former Nissan CEO gets no stronger with age.. Carlos Ghosn finally received 10 minutes in a Japanese courtroom Tuesday, and the prosecution case against him looks no better now than it did when the former Nissan CEO was arrested way back on Nov. 19. One of the strangest cases in the history of international business gets curiouser and curiouser.

title: Sumner Redstone, Family Settle Legal Dispute With Former Companion
summary: Herzer to pay back $3.25 million in gifts from Redstone. Media mogul Sumner Redstone and his family have agreed to settle their long-running legal dispute with his former live-in companion, Manuela Herzer, less than a week before one of the cases was scheduled for trial in California, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Senate Democrats Block Legislation to Press GOP on Shutdown
summary: Move comes hours before Trump is to make his case for a border wall. WASHINGTON-Senate Democrats on Tuesday blocked the chamber from considering bipartisan foreign-policy legislation in a bid to pressure Republicans to reopen the government, just hours before President Trump was expected to make a national appeal to end the stalemate on the grounds of national security.

title: Apple's Tim Cook Gets 22% Increase in Pay
summary: Compensation surges to $15.7 million as iPhone maker tops financial targets but faces slowdown. Apple Inc. rewarded Chief Executive Tim Cook and other top executives with a big boost in compensation for fiscal 2018, when the iPhone maker blew past annual sales and profit goals but faced slowing momentum for its most popular device.

title: Herb Kelleher
summary: The capitalist who 'democratized the skies.'. If you were aboard a Southwest Airlines flight in its early years, you might have bumped into a man dressed like Elvis, as in Presley. That would have been Herb Kelleher, the airline's founder who never fit the mold of a corporate executive but whose achievements rank with the best of them. By the time he died late last week at age 87, Southwest had become America's largest domestic air carrier.

title: A California-Nevada Tax Brawl
summary: The Supreme Court gets another chance on state sovereign immunity.. Last June the Supreme Court overturned a 50-year precedent and let states impose sales taxes on businesses with no physical presence in those states. On Wednesday the Justices will consider whether to repudiate another precedent that lets taxpayers and businesses seek legal redress for harassment and injuries by other states.

title: Europe's Boom That Wasn't
summary: A downturn looms before the upturn has fully materialized.. Europeans are growing antsy that their recent economic boom is winding down, and the big question has to be: What boom? The Continent finds itself in the position of bracing for the next downturn without having fully benefited from the upturn.

title: Price Drugs According to What They Do
summary: A simple reform to improve outcomes and control costs.. In the U.S., medications are priced and sold by the pill, capsule or fluid ounce. A better approach would be to charge different prices for a medicine based on the disease for which it is prescribed. While the current drug-purchasing system is too complex to reform overnight, there is a simple change that could improve health outcomes and control spending: disease-specific rebates.

title: Have We Got a Carbon Tax 'Dividend' for You
summary: Rent seekers, virtue signalers and green lobbyists will love it. Taxpayers not so much.. This could be the year Congress tries to enact the mother of all taxes, a carbon tax-a levy on the use of oil, natural gas and coal. Everything that is fabricated, grown, operated or moved is made possible by hydrocarbons. That makes the carbon tax different from a mere consumption or excise tax. The latter is attached to purchasing-spend more, pay more. A carbon tax is a tax on existence, because all aspects of living require energy, and hydrocarbons provide 80% of America's energy, more for the rest of the world. And hydrocarbons are used to create or build everything else that produces energy.

title: What Trump Means by 'America First'
summary: His historical antecedent? Not Charles Lindbergh but the 'belligerent isolationism' of Sen. William Borah.. There's more than one type of isolationist. Some in the 1930s were pacifists on philosophical grounds; others opposed Franklin Roosevelt's support for the British, fearing it would drag America into a European war; and some even admired the Nazis. The America First Committee, for which Charles Lindbergh was spokesman, contained the full range of these views. Since President Trump has made "America First" his calling card, one might assume that Lindbergh & Co. are the antecedents of his foreign policy.

title: High Tax Rates Aren't Optimal
summary: Nobody really thinks a top rate of 70% or 80% is a good idea in the real world.. Paul Krugman, a Nobel Prize winner, wears his learning lightly in his New York Times column, all the better apparently to focus on his real purpose: characterizing anyone associated with "the right" as an evil idiot.

title: Democrats Contend With the 'Anger Translator'
summary: Nancy Pelosi will have a hard time keeping the ultraprogressives in her caucus quiet.. The White House Correspondents' Dinner in 2015 included an ingenious skit featuring President Obama and the comedian Keegan-Michael Key. As Mr. Obama stood at a lectern offering vapid pleasantries about White House press coverage, his "anger translator," portrayed by Mr. Key, lurked behind him acting out what the president was really thinking.

title: Could Emergency Powers Build the Wall?
summary: Trump says he can move without consent of Congress, but legal scholars are divided.. President Trump has threatened repeatedly to invoke emergency powers to build his wall on the southern border if Congress refuses to provide funds for it. By the time you read this, Mr. Trump may have announced this step in his address from the Oval Office.

title: 'The Longest Line on the Map' Review: The End of the Road
summary: It seemed like a great idea, linking the Americas with a rail line or highway. Landscape challenges and corruption got in the way. Charles R. Morris reviews "The Longest Line on the Map" by Eric Rutkow.. Everybody loves a shaggy dog story. A good one should be long and implausible but still on the edge of possibility. The chronicle at the heart of Eric Rutkow's "The Longest Line on the Map" seems to qualify. The story involves the decades-long attempt to construct thousands of miles of railway-and, later, highway-to "link the Americas."
